Centre for Population Change</AuthEnty>         <othId>The <I>General Household Survey</I> (GHS) data were originally collected and compiled by the Office for National Statistics and made available by the UK Data Archive. The principal work of extracting and harmonising the GHS data across annual rounds was carried out by Dr Eva Beaujouan while a Research Fellow at the Centre for Population Change, assisted by Dr Mark Lyons-Amos, and directed by Professor M\ufffd\ufffdire N\ufffd\ufffd Bhrolch\ufffd\ufffdin and Professor Ann Berrington.</othId>       </rspStmt>       <prodStmt>         <producer>Office for National Statistics. Social Survey Division</producer>         <copyright>Copyright of project data: E. Beaujouan, M. N\ufffd\ufffd Bhrolch\ufffd\ufffdin, A. Berrington and J. Falkingham. The original General Household Survey data remain Crown copyright. vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/e3d42c1b-deab-4acf-9069-8e7b4e412d1c">STERILIZATION (SEX)</keyword>         <topcClas>Childbearing, family planning and abortion - Health</topcClas>         <topcClas>Population studies - Population, vital statistics and censuses</topcClas>         <topcClas>Family life and marriage - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The aim of the Centre for Population Change (CPC) <I>General Household Survey</I> (GHS) Database project was twofold. The first objective was to create a new data resource, assembling in a single data file, in harmonised form, a time series of repeated cross-sectional GHS survey data on demographic histories relating to fertility, marriage and cohabitation. The second objective was to use this new data resource to analyse the changing dynamics of childbearing and partnership over recent decades, and especially to examine the determinants of the changing timetable of fertility and partnership.<br> <br> The data are a subset, in harmonised form, of all GHS rounds 1979-2009, with those from 1998-2009 being Special Licence editions plus the previous 1972-2004 Time Series GHS Dataset. From 2008, the GHS was known as the <I>General Lifestyle Survey</I>  until it closed in 2012. See the UK Data Service <a href="http://discover.ukdataservice.ac.uk/series/?sn=200019" title="General Lifestyle Survey">General Lifestyle Survey</a> series webpage for the original catalogue records.<br> <br> Further information about construction of the database can be found in the documentation. Information about the overall project can be found on the ESRC <a href="http://www.esrc.ac.uk/my-esrc/grants/RES-625-28-0001/read" title="Centre for Population Change: Understanding Population Change in the 21st Century">Centre for Population Change: Understanding Population Change in the 21st Century</a> award page.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>Fertility, marriage, cohabitation, household composition, education, age, separation, divorce, marital dissolution, partnership dissolution, contraception, sterilisation.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd event="start" date="1979-01-01T00:00:00Z">1979</timePrd>         <timePrd event="end" date="2009-01-01T00:00:00Z">2009</timePrd>         <timePrd>Note: the demographic histories in the GHS allow analysis of demographic event rates and populations at risk for time periods before 1979; coverage depends on the topic in question.</timePrd>         <nation>Great Britain</nation>         <geogUnit>Countries</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <anlyUnit> Families/households</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Respondents to the GHS between 1979-2009.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Time Series</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>29 rounds in all as there was no GHS fielded in 1997 and 1999.</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>Office for National Statistics. Social Survey Division</dataCollector>         <sampProc>Multi-stage stratified random sample</sampProc>         <deviat>647,770 cases</deviat>         <collMode>Compilation or synthesis of existing material</collMode>         <collMode>The original GHS used face-to-face interview and self-completion to gather information.</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Five weights are supplied in the dataset: (a) The original ONS weights, which are available for GHS rounds 1996-2009 only;  (b) Four further CPC-generated weights are supplied: two for respondents to the GHS questionnaire as a whole, and two for respondents to the Family Information section of the questionnaire. In each case, a standardised and unstandardized version is supplied. The generation of these weights is documented in the article by Beaujouan, Brown and N\ufffd\ufffd Bhrolch\ufffd\ufffdin (2011) cited in the User Guide and in the References section.</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Special licence required</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about  usage.<br/>Additional special conditions of use also apply. See <a href='http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/conditions.aspx'>terms and conditions</a>   for further information.<br/><br/> In addition, the UK Data Service  is required to request permission from the depositor prior to supplying the data.<br/>Available to UK applicants only.<br/><br/>Please note:<br/>Since these data pose a higher risk of disclosure than data made available under the standard End User Licence they have additional special conditions attached to them.  Any registered user requiring access to these data will have to be accredited by the UK Statistics Authority as an Approved Researcher.<br/><br/>To apply for accreditation a user will need to complete forms that will require: (i) evidence that he/she is a fit and proper person and details  about the purpose of the research; (ii) an online order for the data; (iii) a signed declaration that he/she understands the confidentiality obligations owed to those data including its physical security.<br/><br/>The evidence to be adduced will include previous research projects and publications. New users may need to provide the contact details of a senior  member of staff who can vouch for them. The research purpose form will ask for information about the intended use of the data, a justification for access and planned outputs.<br/><br/>Users who obtain access to these data are required to read and follow the <a href='http://www.data-archive.ac.uk/media/132701/UKDA171-SS-MicrodataHandling.pdf'>Microdata Handling and Security: Guide to Good Practice</a>.<br/><br/>To apply for access, users should use the Download/Order link on this page and will be directed to the relevant forms as part of the ordering process.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relPubl>N\ufffd\ufffd Bhrolch\ufffd\ufffdin, M., Beaujouan, \ufffd\ufffd. and Berrington, A.
